conclusion: Objects A and B are released above a flat, level table.
Gravity accelerates objects A and B downward until they touch the tabletop and/or the nearest already-standing blocks.
Object A is positioned above blocks C and D, and object B is positioned above blocks E and F.
Object A touches block C and the edge of block D, while object B touches block F and the edge of block E.
The impact of objects A and B is gentle, with no appreciable sideways impulse.
The existing blocks C, D, E, and F are not knocked over due to the gentle impact.
Static friction between the blocks and the table is sufficient to keep all blocks upright once they have come into mutual contact.
Objects A and B slide very slightly until all the vertical faces are flush.
The six rectangular blocks stand next to one another in two rows on the tabletop.
Nothing topples or slides off the table; all blocks come to rest upright under gravity.
